article:
The term 'spring' is often used to name periods of political liberalization.

*Revolutions of 1848, sometimes referred to as the Spring of Nations or
Springtime of the Peoples *Arab Spring, another term for the Middle East North
Africa protest of 2010-2011 *Beijing Spring a period of political liberalization
in the People's Republic of China in the late 1970s *Cedar Spring was a chain of
demonstrations in Lebanon (especially in the capital Beirut) triggered by the
assassination of the former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri on February 14,
2005. *Croatian Spring a movement for Croatian language rights and cultural
identity in the Second Yugoslavia in the early 1970s *Damascus Spring period in
Syria following the death of Hafez al-Assad *Harare Spring sometimes used to
describe the period in Zimbabwe after the power sharing agreement between Robert
Mugabe and Morgan Tsvangirai *Kathmandu Spring sometimes
used to describe the 1990 People's Movement, as well as subsequent democracy
movements. *Prague Spring a period of political
liberalization in the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic in the late 1960s *Riyadh
Spring sometimes used to describe the period in Saudi Arabia during the early
2000s. *Rangoon Spring sometimes used to describe the period leading
up to the 8888
Uprising [http://www.mkgandhi.org/articles/other%20Gandhis.htm
] http://www.teaandtoast.ie/?p=1041 *The 2012 Quebec student
protests movement is also called the 'Maple' Spring, from the French "Printemps
Ãrable" which sounds phonetically similar to "Printemps Arabe" (Arab Spring).
"Printemps QuÃ©bÃ©cois" for "Quebec Spring" is also used. *Seoul Spring a period
of democratization in South Korea in the late 1970s and early 1980s *Tehran
Spring sometimes used to describe the period in Iran during the presidency of
Mohammad Khatami
